unreliability_text: * Estimate is based on small numbers so should be interpreted with caution.
Compare.graph_title: Trends in Cold Stress: Cold Stress Hospitalizations - Age-Adjusted Rate 2005 to 2016

info.info_how_calculated:
NYC residents admitted to a NYC hospital during the months of October-April for the effects of reduced temperature or excessive or extreme cold due to weather conditions or undetermined cause (International Classification of Diseases, 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 991, E901.0, E901.8, E901.9, or E988.3 if admitted before October 1, 2015; International Classification of Diseases, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes X31, T68, T69, T33, T34 if admitted on or after October 1, 2015). Residents with a diagnostic code for excessive cold due to man-made conditions were excluded (ICD-9-CM code E901.1 if admitted before October 1, 2015; ICD-10-CM code W93 if admitted on or after October 1, 2015). Annual data is based on date of admission, and include those who were admitted with a diagnosis of cold-related illness in any principal or other diagnostic field. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department.

 

Counts are summed by 5-year age groups and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.
info.info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data, United States Census

unreliability_text: * Estimate is based on small numbers so should be interpreted with caution.
Compare.graph_title: Trends in Cold Stress: Cold Stress Hospitalizations - Estimated Annual Rate 2005 to 2016

info.info_how_calculated: NYC residents admitted to a NYC hospital during the months of October-April for the effects of reduced temperature or excessive or extreme cold due to weather conditions or undetermined cause (International Classification of Diseases, 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 991, E901.0, E901.8, E901.9, or E988.3 if admitted before October 1, 2015; International Classification of Diseases, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes X31, T68, T69, T33, T34 if admitted on or after October 1, 2015). Residents with a diagnostic code for excessive cold due to man-made conditions were excluded (ICD-9-CM code E901.1 if admitted before October 1, 2015; ICD-10-CM code W93 if admitted on or after October 1, 2015). Annual data is based on date of admission, and include those who were admitted with a diagnosis of cold-related illness in any principal or other diagnostic field. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. Counts are divided by the population using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates and expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.
info.info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data, United States Census

Compare.graph_title: Trends in Cold Stress: Cold Stress Hospitalizations - Number 2005 to 2016

info.info_how_calculated:
NYC residents admitted to a NYC hospital during the months of October-April for the effects of reduced temperature or excessive or extreme cold due to weather conditions or undetermined cause (International Classification of Diseases, 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 991, E901.0, E901.8, E901.9, or E988.3 if admitted before October 1, 2015; International Classification of Diseases, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes X31, T68, T69, T33, T34 if admitted on or after October 1, 2015). Residents with a diagnostic code for excessive cold due to man-made conditions were excluded (ICD-9-CM code E901.1 if admitted before October 1, 2015; ICD-10-CM code W93 if admitted on or after October 1, 2015). Annual data is based on date of admission, and include those who were admitted with a diagnosis of cold-related illness in any principal or other diagnostic field. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department.

 

Note: Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.
info.info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

unreliability_text: *** Number is suppressed for confidentiality reasons.
